posts.com:
Advice on making a successful advice post on /o/:

If you are looking to get advice on a possible car purchase or car related problem, be sure to include:

What car or cars you are looking at or as detailed a description of the problem as possible. Include make, model, year, mileage, condition, any know faults, the asking price, and what your budget is!

If people have to ask you for every detail, you aren't going to get many replies!

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
1.)Get financing ahead of time/know your credit. You always want to have a financing option in hand before you go to a dealership. Nothing wrong with negotiating a better deal with them once you get there, but never go in empty handed. This way you can have idea of how much you can afford to spend, and what a car is going to cost you

2.)Do your research. Know what values KBB/NADA/Edmunds/TrueCar are listing for the cars you are interested in. Also know what other dealerships are listing similar cars for. Dealerships will prey on the uninformed, so make sure that you are

2b.)If you don't know enough about cars to inspect one yourself, arrange to get any used car inspected or bring someone who DOES know what to look for. It's surprisingly easy to polish up a turd and get it passed inexperienced eyes

3.)Never take the first offer, unless it's a place like CarMax that doesn't negotiate. Dealerships know the game, and they always get a certain number of people to bite on the first offer. make them work a little to get your business

4.)You can negotiate on more than the price. Oil changes, services plans, warranties, accessories are all fair game.

5.)In today's world, internet sales departments are your friend. You can send a blanket email to 3 or 4 dealerships and get them to compete for your business, let them haggle with each other before you ever haggle with them

6.)Get them to print you a Buyers Order for any car you are seriously, that is what you negotiate from. It will look like pic related, and itemize every line of the sale. Don't let them 4 square you or hand write shit on a piece of paper. Get a buyers order

7.)Never be afraid to walk away from a deal. If you have a bad feeling, sleep on it. There will always be other cars

I'm going to repeat one more time:
>A REPUTABLE MECHANIC THAT ISN'T A GOD DAMN NIGGER RETARD

>Plus why live in a world where you understand nothing, and do nothing.

It's more an understanding of the time it takes to really understand and master all caveats of a given repair (the little things like lubing this or loctiting that and not accidentally lubing or loctiting something you shouldn't and fucking yourself). The internet is not always right and sometimes a repair that seems to work great the first day will fail soon after if it's not done correctly, usually leaving people blaming the part rather than their install. If I do something, I'll do it once and will be doing it as a beginner at least for that particular model of car, if I hand it to someone that works on that car day in and day out they will be doing it for the 50th time that month and have it down to a reflex. There's something to be said for that. Also, a good mechanic that specializes in your car will know if anything is out of place. The V8 tuner that works on my Corvette could immediately point at every mod the car had from stock like the C6 Z06 shocks (on a C5) that I didn't even know it had from the previous owner (it's not obvious like an aftermarket intake tube, you have to just know what they look like to notice). It's about the reflexive knowledge of exactly how the car is supposed to look and when something is out of place, like you looking where you keep your wallet and keys and knowing in .2 seconds when your wallet isn't where it should be. I used to repair video game consoles years ago in college and if I had a choice between me doing a repair for the first time or the 100th time, I'd def. choose the me doing it for the 100th time.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>26273697
No, there are ways to download popular FSMs and aftermarket manuals. Unlike the bad old days there are many more places to read to learn theory of operation and videos to watch the tasks you'll be performing.

Reading, reading online (especially forums which are unsurpassed for useful content), videos etc in combination will get you where you need to go. Study each task as you need to perform them and buy appropriate tools for the task rather than in anticipation and you'll be fine. Soon you'll become comfortable by understanding theory of operation and general wrenching techniques.

Slow is smooth and smooth is fast. NEVER hurry or get frustrated.
Take pictures of everything as you remove or disassemble parts. Take more than you imagine necessary.
ORGANIZE REMOVED HARDWARE! I punch holes in cardboard (I collect boxes for this) to hold bolts and screws in order. If I've a new gasket I trace it on cardboard with a sharpie then make holes (an X made by pocket knife grips well).
Clear plastic fishing organizers from Walmart are golden. I leave notes beneath the lids.

Many errors are due to being sloppy so don't.

I keep a pail of water, dish detergent and cloths or rags to clean my hands often. I also wear nitrile and other work gloves because they're faster than hand washing and cheap enough the cost doesn't matter.

A decent bright LED headlamp (I avoid the expensive ones) is fucking gold as task lighting. Holding flashlights is a waste of hand.

its because they are the best machine for remote off road use. simple as. you can get parts across the large country in remote areas. everyone is aware of the 'issues', and with enough money you can 'fix' the issues (fact:99% of people do not need to 'fix' the track). burgers don't get it and can use a jeep off road because they are never more than 3hrs from a main road (and a mcdonalds). a land rover will get you there, but a land cruiser will get you home heh.

>>26274443
I actually do work remote and there’s far more Hiluxs than 79s.

Most 79s I see are literally suburban larpers with the full kings/arb catalogue and not a speck of mud on the thing.

Dual cab Hilux can take 4 people and all their work gear and be actually comfortable and safe to drive.

79s are loud, cramped, dangerous and underpowered. All for a 50 grand premium.

The world has moved on, the country is crisscrossed by big open tarmac now and parts can just be sent JIT to any nearby town.

The only person I know who uses a 79 properly needs to tow more than any Ute can take but didn’t want to pony up for a chopped 2/300. It was actually cheaper to get a 79 and fix the tracks and fill it with as many mod cons as you can manage.

It’s still painful to sit in the thing for long periods, it’s still noisy, and it’s still going to be dangerous in an accident.

posts.sub: Aerodynamics of Camper Tops and Solutions
posts.com: Hello /o/. I was wondering, generally speaking, how do camper tops contribute to or decrease the aerodynamics of a truck? My truck has been getting worse and worse fuel economy recently, and although it didn't start with the installation of this camper top, I suspect it is contributing to the issue. There is a slight gap between the camper top and the cab, and air is able to flow through this area and add resistance. How should I go about covering up and sealing this gap? Thank you.

posts.name: BigC
posts.com:
>>26273698
i doubt that gap is the issue, the issue is the giant flat back causing a low pressure zone, and increased drag
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jAYP6pWrdkc

posts.name: BigC
posts.com:
>>26273711
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Semi-trailer_aerodynamic_device
scroll down to trailer tails, that is a possible solution to reduced fuel economy

posts.com: I thought I would also ask, if anybody has any experience with these third generation Rangers, I'm curious as to how I can improve my fuel economy. I have the 2.3L Duratec with a manual transmission. Several months ago, I was getting 25 mpg. regularly, even with the camper top. Recently, I've been getting around 23-24, and my driving habits haven't changed. Could it be old oxygen sensors running the engine rich? I still have the originals on this truck which is 21 years old.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26273751
It entirely depends on how much you drive in the city vs highway. Unless you account for this variable you can't really be sure you're getting lower mileage. You might just be spending a few miles less on the highway than city which could make all the difference.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26273751
Do you have winter? Winter blend gas and winter driving habits usually drops your mpg 1-3mpg. You're going to know the difference the cap makes within a tank or two. If it's continuing to drop you got other issues.

posts.com:
>>26273751
Check your spark plugs, it tells the tale of your vehicle. Are your tires aired to the same as your control test? The weight of the cap alone might lose you 1mpg since those engines are gutless.

>>26272860
Think about the difference between an r6 and an r1 from both a buyer and manufacturer perspective

>same market
>effectively same parts
>likely similar quality parts
>likely cost almost the same to build
>r1 sells for significantly more
>r1 makes more power and is cooler
>r1 has more torque and is more usable on the street

So naturally the r1 makes more profit and sells better. The only real market for an r6 is for those who ride track, prefer 600s, and have the capital to buy new. Selling it as a track only bike makes the most sense. Kawi made their 600 more streetable years ago with the 636 and made it cheaper than the r6 which seems to have worked, but since its outsold by the ninja 650 10:1 it won’t be around for much longer

The cbr600rr is already gone from the states and costs as much as a cbr1000rr, super niche but jap brands do have a history of reserving special retarded models for japan and sea only

You literally just need to stop. First and foremost your physically addicted to both the action and the chemical. Finding something that mimics the physical act will help immensely while using a nic gum or patch.
You use the patch or gum to progressively lower the amount you take in each day, and supplement with another act that mimics smoking as an activity. get yourself a 0% nic vape or something, or just do away with patches and gum and work yourself down from a 12% esalt to a 3%, then mix a custom 1.5% until you're at 0%.

Most important is addressing both things at the same time. Your brain needs the chemical, but it wants the activity. Target both with whatever you do.

posts.name: BigC

>>26259740
here's the instructions copy pasted, you keep making a fool of yourself lol
1. Place the boards in their fully deployed position. In most cases, it may be easier to remove the motors from the motor linkages to allow the steps to fully deploy, and proceed with the rest of the process.
2. Verify that the pinch weld holes are lining up with the holes for the linkages. You may need to enlarge the holes in the pinch weld if they do not line up or are catching the bolt threads as you install the steps.
3. Verify that the rear of the running board is flush with the rear linkage. If it is not, adjust the running board forward so that the end cap is flush with the linkage.
4. Make sure that ALL HARDWARE IS TIGHTENED PROPERLY.
5. Have someone walk the length of the board, taking bouncing steps or shifting their weight up and down as they walk. DO NOT JUMP on the running boards. Only shift your weight up and down while moving the entire length of the running board, like you are performing a suspension check.
6. With the boards still in the down position, loosen the button head Torx head bolts that go through the pinch weld. DO NOT loosen the hex head bolts on the back of the rocker panel. Then, either have someone sit on the center of the board or put some weight on the center of the board. While there is weight on the board, retighten the button head bolts going through the pinch weld.
7. Remove the weight from the board, and try moving the board up to the completely stowed position. Check to see if the board clears the pinch weld. If it clears, reinstall the motors and complete the installation. In some cases where the pinch weld is more uneven, you may need to do this complete procedure a second or third time. If the step still does not clear the pinch weld after several seating attempts, please continue on to Step 8.

>>26271398
>how to gun a gun in poland
In order to get it you have to be a member of shooting club for at least 3 months, where you learn how to use weapons, you're being watched and owner of the club decides whether or not, you can be trusted and he lets you take an license exam.
This exam will check your gun laws knowledge (also penalties for gun related crimes), safety procedures, structure of weapons and rules of some sport disciplines. Test consists of 20 questions with three possible answers of which only one is correct. First 5 are about laws and have to be answered 100% correctly in remaining 15 you can have 2 mistakes. In my opinion this test is rather easy and learning for 3 evenings is enough to pass it.
Once you pass this test you can take practical exam. You will have to prove your shooting abilities. 5 shots from pistol, rifle and shotgun. Accuracy matters (not with the shotgun obviously) as much, as safe and careful weapon use. Checking chamber, pointing barrel in direction of target, test shot after unloading.. all this stuff.
Ufff... let's say it's done. Congratulations, you're half way through ;)
Now you have to be examined by the doctors. Check-up is complex, I mean it. It takes one complete day of walking from door to door. Even psychotechnical abilities like speed of reaction are examined. On top of it there's a conversation with psychiatrist, who gives opinion about your mental health.
Now you gather your paperwork and send it through your club to Polish Association of Sport Shooting (PZSS), they issue a license which has to be renewed every year. It is called "important reason for possesion firearms" It's renewed every year by starting in shooting competitions.

Once he's done with his paperwork, you will finally get your weapon permit. When you complete this path they cannot deny you. Police gives you certain number of certificates which allow you to buy gun. You can apply for 5, 10, 15 whatever. They usually suggest you how many is best, it depends on the chief of police, how many he's willing to give at beginning. Those certificates are only way to buy a firearm. Every seller will need them from you, as he has to inform police about selling his gun and return this certificate to the police. You also have to register your weapon within 5 working days since you buy it. It will be noted, with serial number, in a little red book (picrel), that certifies you're a legal gun owner. You have to carry this book on you anytime you got your weapon with you.
Ah... don't forget to buy safe! It needs to be certified steel safe where weapons and ammo will be kept at all times. Nobody else but permit holder can have keys or combination to it.
Important: Whenever you use all your certificates, you can apply for more and you will get them. Your local policeman will come again, check whether all registered gun are still in your posession (better be ;), storage conditions are correct and you're not beating your wife ;) There are no limits in number of guns. One of my friends has over 300.

It was Australia wide.
Private conversions weren't super popular but "factory" Holden/Ford converted dual fuel systems (Holden ones were technically done by HSV because of liability issues iirc) were actually extremely popular.
Reliability was great, power loss was minimal (and sometimes was gained on dedicated LPG setups), and paying less than half the price of patrol for like 10% worse mileage AND still having the option to switch between both in an instant was extremely appealing.
In SA petrol stations that serve LPG are becoming harder to find as they can't justify the build or upkeep of the special pumps, and rural areas are basically getting cut off by the gas supplier because its not economically viable.
I think its a fucking shame, because it burns cleaner, has a higher octane and is dirt cheap. My dream car is a manual HSV VF wagon on dual fuel - but that won't help me if I can't buy LPG.

posts.name: fujiwarastickershop.jp
posts.com:
>>26274024
I'll reiterate a couple of points and add on a few things from the last time I talked about it, a large reason we didn't want to work on it is because of the aforementioned but there's a large list of things that piled on top of one another and we just don't feel like doing it anymore.

- We're spending money on production that could be used for that sticker on other products instead. Pre-orders are gone, and we don't want to create a 6 week lead time (pre-order + production).

- I worked briefly with desuprint who informed me of issues with production, a large one being that Taiyo works in Inkscape primarily and the design would have to be completely rebuilt in Illustrator along with the white ink layer. desuprint also had the foil we wanted to do it on, however he has told me a while ago he is unable to reproduce it. The cost in paying him to print the stickers would be exploiting and underpaying him, or it would end up charging the customer out the ass. Paying over $10 for a sticker is stupid, and that's ironic because my store will only offer tracked shipping in the future and I apologize for any international orders because shipping is literally going to eat people's asses.

- Many things have been on my backlog for a while. In the past 6 months, nearly every original Taiyo design has been under renovation along with new(er) projects. I reflected over my FOTM drop and figured it wasn't something I wanted to force myself to do like I did before after Grandmasterslices gave me input that made me realize I was pushing myself way too hard and getting frustrated over nothing.

tl;dr no thanks, see you when the store is open someday.

I own three cars. A daily driver, a weekend track toy, and a comfy cruiser for long distance trips or formal events.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
1. Americans would rather pay twice as much for a bigger vehicle. Rangers are smaller than their wife's Explorer, only poorfags bought them and companies moved to Transits for fleet vehicles. Eurovans won in this case.

2. Because Americans want big trucks. For all the bloated dimensions today, most of it is cosmetic. My '85 F-series is a fucking road hog and it doesn't even have duallies. It's also hard to control and slides everywhere if you're not careful shifting. Which speaks to how much better truck transmissions are now and how ECS/ABS has made truck driving easy enough for the layman.

3. Kei trucks don't pass emissions or crash testing laws, so they're defacto banned on that basis alone. American road laws do not consistently make categories for "low speed" vehicles or very small utility vehicles as Japan does. Just in general, Americans want a vehicle that can reliably go on a highway. 4-cyl Rangers have a hard enough time making it to 55 under load, let alone a normal freeway speed at 75. Most people would rather get a bigger truck in this case. Additionally, cabover trucks that do fit all this are much bigger and already sold by Isuzu, often with a full size cargo van and a liftgate.

4. Americans are fat and have been getting fatter. This is an actual problem, Californians might be able to fit into a Ranger without trouble but when most of your buyers are from Alabama, Kentucky, Ohio and Illinois your little truck won't be able to fit one of them let alone two. Note that two "plus size" Americans are equivalent to most Kei trucks' rated payload, so most Americans are literally too fat for JDM vehicles.

Just look at the popular trucks: Ram 3500s with extra legroom, a step, and multiple assists and integrated bluetooth. A fatass can easily step in, lean back, and not worry about the vehicle sagging or the seat breaking or the seatbelt not buckling.

>>26245261
Could be a number of things but the most likley is that water (which is a byproduct from combustion) is precipitating in your cold exhaust pipe, and that when your exhaust heats up (as the engine does) it makes it out the end of the exhaust still in gaseous form. What you're seeing is condensation, not smoke. If it is smoke it could be your piston rings that seal better as your engine internals heat up, which causes your cold engine to consume a bit of oil.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26248477
We'll start with the most serious issue: The cracked block.
If it was cracked externally, you'd doubtless have found the leak by now.
If it was cracked internally, you definitely notice symptoms such as fluid contamination. Given you state that's not happening, nor is it building too much pressure, then I'm optimistic you can rule out the block/head/head gasket.

Likewise, if the EGR manifold/cooler assembly has started leaking, you'll be able to tell as exhaust gases would be present to some degree in the coolant, darkening it. If not darkening it, then a sniffer test would detect the presence of coolant. They're a simple kit to buy and use.

Failing that, we're left with the wet intake manifold as the most likely cause of the three you've listed.
Testing it (and the EGR manifold, if it comes to it) is easy - if a little awkward.
Basically block one pipe, and find some way to fit a tyre valve to the other. Inflate to 20 psi, use water/suds to make sure your pipe block/valve arent leaking and observe any pressure drop. Over, say, half an hour. A leaking component will have lost it's pressure.

Or you can remove the components completely, then submerge them like a tyre tube and look for bubbles.

Also, take out your spark plugs. If it's the EGR or the intake, then ALL the plugs should have signs of burning coolant.
If only one or two plugs have it, then it's an engine issue.
The coolant-fouled plug is on the right

posts.com:
>>26249695
As per >>26249793, I'd start with the right oil. The cold index at 5 is fine, but the hot index - at 30 - is less than the 40 recommended, meaning lower oil pressures at operating temps.

Because it only happened once, I wouldn't worry too much about it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Does it help or hinder tire alignment that electric cars have 4 independent motors instead of one motor/driveshaft powering all the wheels? Debating with a friend, one of us thinks it's easier because each wheel can have sensors and adjust alignment as needed, one of us thinks it's worse because there's nothing mechanical keeping the system in sync.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26251509
>Electronic on-the-fly wheel alignment adjustment
Jesus I can't think of anything more horrifying. Luckily, I don't ever see that happening on mass market vehicles; the alignment will be held rigid by threaded bolt members or bolted eccentric cam washers.
Having four wheel motors won't have any effect on that setup because the motors will be "inboard", meaning they drive the wheels from inside the sprung mass of the vehicle, dividing the torsional stress of acceleration between the motor's mounts, the driveshaft and the suspension mounts.

Even if the motors were all hub mounted, the only thing it would do is increase the stress of acceleration on the suspension mounts, making them more likely to wear earlier, which could *then* impact alignment.
Stronger components/bushings would negate that, however.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26250095
On the 122, it's not really so simple. There's a manifold block that bolts to the side of the head, and this block is where the hot coolant flows out of the engine from and into the radiator. The thermostat housing bolts onto it, and it has the ports for the coolant level and the coolant temperature sensors. And also the EGR gasses flow through it (it does have vacuum modulated EGR). But, closing off the EGR valve would only prevent the EGR gasses from continuing into the intake, it would NOT prevent the EGR gasses from entering this manifold and potentially entering the coolant loop (if there is a crack here). So "ripping out the EGR" would involve at minimum some kind of blockoff plate custom made for the shape of this manifold, and the shadetree tools I've got don't extend to a mill. But believe me, I've thought about it.

Driving well, in my opinion, is being able to predict shit other people are going to do and avoiding it. When you're out there on the road pay attention to your surroundings and drive for the conditions. Leave your fucking ego at home and LET SHIT GO:

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26264482
>I'll try but again I think the battery and the power is fine.
The battery might be fine, but if it's not getting to your starter because of a bad battery cable it's not going to help you. I guess I'd measure the voltage to the connection marked S (the skinny wire) while someone cranks the key inside. If it's 12V the problem is your power wire, the ground strap from the engine to the body, the ground cable from the body to the battery, or the starter itself is shot. You can eliminate the grounds as a potential cause by running a jumper from the negative of the battery to the starter housing and see if it still won't start.

If you're not getting 12V on the S connection, possible culprits are neutral safety switch or ignition switch.

Just an idea, you did try taking it out of park and putting it back in kind of hard right in case your NSS isn't quite engaged?

They're targa top, not t top. The price is very decent for those miles, I've been seeing low mileage ones selling for 18-30k over the past year, with the prices finally dropping a reasonable bit in recent months. You could drive it, enjoy it, and sell it off for a small profit most likely.

Also, doesn't have 410hp(just going off your highend), closest would be a Z06, but those are hardtop only. The 01-04 LS1's dyno anywhere from 310-335rwhp(not counting the occasional factory freak like any other car), and the 97-00 models go anywhere from 280-310 range from my personal experience.

The reason for the difference is cam changes, pup cat removal, and intake manifold change in the later years, along with other minor things.

When looking at radio waves and antennas you need to understand how a VHF signal resonates, and how it would be impossible for an internal antenna to resonate on proper fm frequencies. Its a very connected car, youre gonna feel everything you run over. Not in a harsh or abusive way, its pretty comfy, but its definitely more on the sport side than luxury.
Speaking of which there was more body roll than what i was expecting. But thats probably just me since my previous two cars were on coilovers. I still wouldnt get the new Estrema trim with the active suspension, its not worth it.
>Any bad experiences you had that you would've liked to know beforehand?
Infotainment system is sorta shit. Slow, crapped out and given random errors multiple times. Not a big deal and everything still will work, just weird.
>How big of a deal will it be if the dealership isn't close to me?
Cant comment on that yet. Service intervals are every 10k miles which is quite a bit.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Pennzoil NISMO GT-R invasion at 2001 NISMO FESTIVAL!

2001 was a rad year! It was a rare and unique opportunity to see all the Pennzoil-sponsored NISMO GT500 cars together. And let me tells you: the legendary american oil brand stopped to sponsor one of two NISMO official team chassis in 2000 JGTC season, but returned to 2001 for sponsor the ex-LOCTITE ZEXEL GT-R car, becoming the ‘Pennzoil ZEXEL GT-R’ that year. Different from the 1998 R33, and 1999 R34 Pennzoil GT500 champions, and even helping NISMO to win the 2001 season on team standings along with the sister chassis, the Pennzoil ZEXEL GT-R has been updated to ‘Castrol PITWORK GT-R’ for 2002, losing the yellow livery and the Pennzoil sponsor once again. So yes, it means that the Pennzoil ZEXEL GT-R is no longer around us.

Another curious fact, , is that the Pennzoil NISMO GT-R BCNR33 and BNR34 pictured here aren’t “original” cars, but replica based on other chassis. Respectively, they are the 1998 ZEXEL SKYLINE and 1999 CALSONIC SKYLINE repainted as Pennzoil-sponsored cars for NISMO’s heritage.

The original Pennzoil BCNR33 has the low-downforce kit and Nicos GT banner and sometimes can be seen appearing in some events, including the NISMO FESTIVAL itself. The original Pennzoil BNR34 however, has been lost. It was upgraded to ‘Castrol NISMO GT-R’ for 2000 JGTC season, but the car crashed in the first round, being replaced by a new bespoke chassis. NISMO took the IMPUL’s BNR34 late that year to replicate the 1999 JGTC GT500 drivers champion.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26271985
It's about calculating what margin I have.
For example:
A VW Golf 8 is 1789 mm without mirrors and 2073 mm with mirrors.
A Mercedes A250e is 1796 mm without mirrors and 1992 mm with mirrors.
So a Golf 8 is supposedly 7 mm smaller according to the standard width measurement on Wikipedia, but if you look into into it's actually 81 mm larger.
Let's say my garage gives me a 150 mm margin to park the Mercedes: that's managable.
A 69 mm margin for the VW Golf would be too small to go in and out of on a day to day basis.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26271448
>What’s the point of providing an imaginary width where a part of the car is absent?
If you're just working with width, height, and ground clearance, width without mirrors allows for slightly more accurate calculation of frontal area, which (together with coefficient of drag) allows for more accurate calculation of drag at speed.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26272189
Who the fuck cares about drag coefficients once the car left the blueprint state. At best people are interested in range/fuel consumption but this is usually given information.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26272839
Given the coefficient of drag and frontal area together with information about weight, gearing, engine output, it's possible to calculate acceleration at different speeds. Since car manufacturers don't typically publish frontal area, we need to approximate it using ground clearance, height, and width. Using width without mirrors gives a better approximation.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26268766
>tips and tricks
slightly moist bread to remove pilot bearing, can also use socket wrench, nut, bolt and flat screwdriver to keep nut from spinning with bolt
drill hole in rear main seal, stick long screw with blunted tip in (make sure it doesn't touch the sides) and tighten the screw to pop the seal out
loosen crank bolt: wrap old and long v belt around crank and accessory pulley, tuck excess under accessory pulley in direction you're trying to turn the crank bolt
stuck or seized nuts and no heat or penetrating oil available...use ATF and let it soak. more time soaking is always better
if tryong to loosen a nut and no impact, yank the tool on it in a sudden motion rather than applying constant force to avoid breaking or rounding it off.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>26271880
Yes, that's mine. 10/10, would recommend. Drove up the coast from LA to Big Sur to Carmel to Napa last year, wish I could do that every year.

I've never had a problem with the top. The only thing about it is it has some rub marks on it from folding/unfolding but it isn't *that* big of a deal. I drive it top down most of the time anyway. Top up is for bad weather and freeways only, pretty much. Just maintain it with RaggTopp regularly and use a car cover to keep it from fading over time. Same thing with the leather interior, use a leather conditioner regularly and make sure it has UV protectant in it. Keep up on your maintenance. If you're good to your car, it will be good to you back. Find a reputable independent Porsche mechanic and make absolutely sure to get a PPI done on any car you're serious about, and don't be afraid to walk away from one that doesn't pass PPI. Porsches aren't generally super expensive to fix, but they're far from cheap.

A lot of reasons, perception of "poor man's 911" is part of it though. I'm much more familiar with pre-2012 Porsches to perfectly honest, but usually they kept costs down by using downtuned engines, smaller brakes/wheels, smaller car overall since they eliminate the rear seats entire, homogeneous/shared parts. 986/987 generation literally used the doors straight off the 911 and shared a huge amount of parts.
718 takes an especially big price hit though since "4-cylinder Porsche" is irremovably tied to those three numbers.

Every 20k service we’re supposed to check body drains and also re lube the top mechanisms. Not a lot of guys do though desu. Or the evaporator drain clogs and ruins the carpet. Cowl drains clog too and water gets in behind the dash. 92a in general is a drain clogging mess. posts.name: Anonymous

>>26270406
You've never done one then. They are not hard but they are absolutely not easy and will take several hours to do, and this is coming from someone who has probably done 5 or 6 by now.

Not a dealbreaker IMO, my understanding is once you've fixed it it's not an issue again. It's just one of those things you need to think about when considering the price of whatever car you buy. It's a simple job to do step-wise but it seems every bolt is pointing the wrong way for you to reach or connectors require careful fiddling to disconnect. I have big mechanic sausage fingers and it makes removing the belt sprocket bolt annoying.

Oh yeah and to explain to those who don't know the 2.0 thermostat/coolant pump:
It's a mostly plastic body with a metal pump bolted to it on the transmission side - the pump being driven by a tiny timing belt off the balance shaft which sticks out towards the rear of the engine for this purpose. I've never seen a pump go bad but everyone I've seen has codes for the thermostat (either sensor or actuator). Basically the thermostat is 100% computer controlled and has a valve body which can control how much coolant goes to the block and head. My guess is coolant makes it past the valve's seal and into the motor/circuitry.

Hope this helps

posts.com:
Trucker sucks because with modern tech the truck and route is tracked and monitored by corporate.

Back in the boomer days it allowed you to travel cheap and see the country. Take detours and see the sights.
Today the truck is gps tracked every second, you aint venturing anywhere off the route, and you aint taking an extra day to get somewhere.
No more seeing the country for cheap, just what is next to the highway.

Best days of trucking ended when technology to track every rig in real time became cheap and practical to install standard on all vehicles.

You are locked in a depressing box forced to get unhealthy sitting, fighting the bad eyesight that comes with being unhealthy since you need to see to work, while being a poor traveling dad with failed family since being absent is the worst strike against family.
If you get in trouble for drugs or alcohol it can cost you your career, so dont self medicate away the sadness either.
And when you finaly screw up sitting for 70hours getting cut off all day and get into an accident those insurance premiums for you and any employer spike.
Driving for a living is a trick because enough hours on the road lead to accidents, and accidents increase insurance costs so much your bills in your personal life skyrocket.
Only ride share or door dash crap or handyman employee running your own vehicle into the ground at the same time is more of a racket.

Hey bros, my dad was a useless absentee father who didn't teach me shit about cars, so although its embarrassing, I have to turn to u guys. Can someone educate me on tire pressure?

I drive a toyota corolla and the owners manual says that tire pressure should be 30 psi. My mechanic told me i should inflate to about 35-38 psi for better mileage and smoother drive.

But is it wise to disregard the manufacturers guidelines of 30 psi? Wouldn't the excess pressure put a strain on the tire in the long run and make it more prone to bursting or popping?

What does /o/ think?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26273086
I usually go 35, just a slight buffer for if a tire gets slightly low or something.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26273086
30psi is generally for the size and type of tire that the car came on. While increasing tire pressure does reduce rolling resistance and improve fuel economy you're also reducing your contact patch by a lot which reduces grip, increases braking time, and overall reduces handling.

If you increase the pressure, the tire will wear in that contact patch for as long as its at that increased pressure. That basically reduces the life of the tire significantly to the point that you might have saved money in gas but now you're blowing it all buying new tires because you have really good tread on the edges but the center is down to the belts.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26273096

4 psi rule, inflate tyre to a value, then drive at moderate or high speed for 30 mins to warm it up and then check the pressure. if it increases by 4 psi you've got the optimal pressure
however, thats for room temperature. further extension of this rule taking into account changes in ambient temps is every 10 F change in temps is around 0.7 psi increase or decrease depensing on whether its hotter or colder.

>>26273086
30 seems low. The standard for a car is 35 psi.

If you open your driver door in the door sill/frame you will see a sticker that tells you what the tire pressure should be.

Some pro tips:
-Buy a tire pressure gauge and throw it in your glovebox.
-Dont forget to check the spare tire, you don't want to find it under inflated on the side of the road.
-Dont use built in pressure gauges at the air tank they are never calibrated. If you don't have a gauge go inside and buy one or ask to borrow one at the gas station.
-Dont forget to reset tpms.

Sorry you had a shit dad. Good luck anon.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26273086
>But is it wise to disregard the manufacturers guidelines of 30 psi? Wouldn't the excess pressure put a strain on the tire in the long run and make it more prone to bursting or popping?
Glad you asked.

Toyota tends to deliberately underspec their tire PSI rating for comfort reasons. This usually causes wear issues for heavier vehicles like the Sienna, which eats tires if they don't get inflated to 40 PSI. The Corolla does fine at manufacturer's spec and at higher PSI ratings, 35 is fine for whatever you're going to drive it for.

Your tires will show its max pressure it's rated for, it's still significantly higher than what your Corolla will specify.

>>26273096
>If you increase the pressure, the tire will wear in that contact patch for as long as its at that increased pressure.
The effect is not quite as pronounced in radial tires compared to older bias ply tires. It usually takes around 15-20 PSI over specification to really show uneven wear results for a small car like OP is specifying.

posts.com:
Radio should be irrelevant as they're easily added aftermarket for quite cheap.
Facebook Marketplace, Gumtree and friends/relatives should be the best places to look. Idk of Autotrader exists in the UK but I've heard that's an aggregating thing for everything.
Couple options:
Toyota Corolla, Camry, Yaris, Echo - Toyota reliability, but they come at a price premium because of it.
Honda Civic, Accord, Fit - Quite reliable except the V6 autos in the Accord iirc. Honda also has a good reputation, with the price that follows.
Ford Focus, Fiesta - Reasonably reliable and popular, not the same reliability reputation as Hondas and Toyotas so can be found pretty cheap.
Mazda 2, 3, 6 - as above, used to have a reputation for rust issues so I'm not sure how they'll go in Europe, but they're very mechanically sound.
VW Golf, Passat, Jetta, Bora - Reasonably popular in Europe, parts should be relatively available, they're reliable enough but in my very limited experience require a bit more maintenance and have some more issues than others. Nothing really mechanical or drivetrain related though.
Can't really comment on specific Euro pricing, servicing or parts availability as I'm an upsidedowncunt

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
well op's pic if inexpensive swaps are on the table. id recommend 2gr swaps so you don't sacrifice the handling of the rx8 by jamming an engine way too heavy and large into it. the 2gr is only like 50lbs heavier than the wankel anyway. the 2gr is the most common swap into old mr2s for that reason. there is also a channel Frankenstein Motorworks who does a lot of tuning on toyota engines. he's pushing 270 out of a 2ar 4banger naturally aspirated. he sells a lot of parts for the 2gr's too. waiting for the video where he puts his new cams and 2gr into a car and onto a dyno. expecting 300 whp.

the infiniti g37 is 330 stock at crank. a bolt on turbo or probably even just an intake and tune would likely let you push past 300 at wheel.
4th gen acura TL is awd and with a bolt on turbo for its j35 could easily push past 300 wheel.
masda speed 6 is also awd and sits at 270 at crank stock so im sure its possible to push it past 300 but im not sure what it's aftermarket looks like or how sporty it is.
you could also always get a modern civic delsol and k swap it
accords and civics are also cheap but expect to put in a lot more leg work if you want it to be sporty and fast. definitely doable due to the massive aftermarket.
miata. obvious choice but gay.
5th-6th-7th gen celicas are all good candidates obviously.
almost any mitsubishi. bolt ons might be harder to find but if you dont mind a little fabrication you'll be fine.
pretty much anything else worth having is euro and you said jap but there are plenty of solid options and good engines for swaps from euros. worth looking into. realistic cost for a fairly reasonable performance after upgrades would be sitting around 20k-30k USD depending on how you source your engines for swaps.

>>26257464
Year 1:
1: Absolutely hard, but you do get a mobile watchtower trailer which is cool and will be needed here. Vehicles given here aren't great so this is definitely one of the last areas to do in the entire DLC lineup when you're better equipped.
2: Vehicles are a gimmick used only largely on this map, but the difficulty is interesting at least with mud/snow mix. I like the verticality of this one.
3: One of the better areas for starters because the oversized trailers can actually be used rather well here. Hope you like mud, but probably next to Alaska in ease. Vehicles here are kind of nice.
4: It's Season 1 but with even more dickheaded design. You do get the best superheavy truck on this level to compensate. Just like 1, I wouldn't come here until you have better equipment.
Year 2:
5: Distilled bullshit starting off. Not as bad once you get the tempo down and get out some decent ground clearance trucks. Trucks unlocked here are okay but nothing to note since you probably have a decent lineup by now.
6: Gimmick is a Hardcore-Lite mode until you progress far enough, in which is just becomes like 2 but easier. Trucks you get here are good but unlock way too damn late.
7: Easily and without a doubt the single worst DLC of the game. Not really tough but extremely lacking content and feels like recycled assets from the Dakar game they (then) recently released. Vehicles really only work on this level and nowhere else in the game, and the whole level is so short with content you could 100% it in a session or two.
8: Tries to redeem the failure of 7 by adding four massive areas to drive around in. Might be easier than 3 in terms of difficulty.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26257785
Premiums:
Navistar 5000-MV: It's just the BOAR from 3, but with slightly worse fuel usage and a military look. This was the preorder DLC which dominates Michigan/early game, but very quickly falls off later.
Brigadier: This is just a slightly fancier version of the GMC truck you get from Michigan. It's an okay performing truck but I wouldn't really say it's mandatory or good except if you want to be a completionist.
Chevy Apache: Similar to the Navistar in that it's like a truck you will get later on (YAR in vanilla) unlocked earlier to dominate early game.
CAT CT681/International HX 520: Arguably the best premiums because of being free, they make excellent support trucks. The CAT 681 when upgraded with a good engine and highrange is one of the best trucks in the game for moving quick.
Western Star 49X: A big fat heavy truck that is only really good for pulling large trailers. Will fuck you if you play Hard mode due to the extra maintenance costs.
Tatra 813/805: You'll get this one automatically on buying the Year 1 pass. 805 makes for a very good heavy offroad truck until you get a larger toolset to use. Personally used it for the GOAT Zikz on Season 4.
Jeeps: Mediocre scouts with not much ability, even to haul trailers. Might be fine in light dirt but are very useless to do anything serious.
Crocodile: Makes for a good resupply truck, one of the better premiums actually. Similar to the trucks you unlock in Season 1 but without the suspension problems.
Western Star Pack: Aesthetically a cool pack with the 57X, but by this point you've seen this trucks already and have trucks with much better performance considering these are highway/light vocational trucks.
Hercules: Like the Apache, but without the ability to pull a trailer.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26257785
>>26257786
My quick and dirty unofficial guide to starting off:
>Fuck off out of Michigan, head to Russia to beeline it to the Tayga repair mission
>Repair the Tayga, take it back with you to Alaska
>Run some missions in Alaska until you're at a decent enough money/level to start affording better tires
>You want to get off highways ASAP, it'll become a lot easier to deal with thick mud after that point
>In (almost) every case, I is better on road, III better on dirt, and II in mud, so swap to IIs if you get stuck often
>Almost all chains are identical, performing like All-Terrains in mud and Offroads in dirt
>You can force a transmission to act as a semi-automatic by clicking the gear shift to force the transmission to shift for you (mandatory for some of Season 7)
>Pacific trucks despite the lack of AWD have some of the best traction values for tires, best tires in the game are on the heavy Russian scout in the final vanilla region
>Highrange transmission does reduce fuel usage slightly even when idling, while Advanced transmission increases it
>If you have yet to complete the Season 4 DLC or know someone who needs to complete the Season 4 DLC, see if you can find a party trying to unlock the Zikz as it along with the Tayga will carry you through the hardest parts of the game

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26257888
Nah, this game is an absolute dickpunch starting off, especially because Michigan is really muddy until you figure out alternate routes to go around. Alaska has icy roads but those shouldn't be too much a concern if you keep moving. Know at least one person in my group that negatively reviewed it due to being such an early game clusterfuck and I had to carry them through around their first 10 hours of gameplay.

The Tayga along with the Zikz will carry you through the game, don't feel bad about making them your bread and butter until you learn fancier tricks in getting around.

>>26257920
Not really? Lot of the premium trucks are actually not that good, the CAT CT681 is one of my most used trucks because it's got an incredibly power/weight ratio and highrange slams through all but heavy mud and snow, and best part is it's free. If it was still early on you could argue the Navistar is an unbalanced preorder truck but it too has problems like no diff lock and chugs fuel like a motherfucker. Play it similar to the CAT by slamming it in high on highrange and letting it boulder through terrain rather than sink in. Even with just the Year 1 pass the game dumps the Bandit on you and the 805, which is more than enough to get the Zikz.

>Lake Kovd
It is a tough area, but it really is a very pretty area and the borealis at night also helps. I like it and have done decent time there, but it's not a beginner friendly zone. Will have to play through Season 8 more with bad trucks because that may be one of the easiest regions to play in the game now.

>>26273603
I use all my trucks long term because the cost per year rockets downward over time. It's not a matter of brand but model and specific drivetrain so I seek common, reliable hardware. Every truck has flaws so while I have GM trucks when I get one with a 4L60E etc I expect to rebuild that.

My three currently tagged trucks are a 2000 F150, a 1997 F150 and a 1999/2000 mixed Silverado shortbed I bought to flip but kept when the F150 engine hydrolocked (even the "fixed" 4.2s do). I swapped out the engine with a used motor because I've had the truck since 2004 so it was well worth it (and I really like the long bed with the Tommy Gate I added). All those were high volume vehicles so parts are easy to source. I do all my own work except machining.

Investigate trucks that suit your use case, then ask mechanics (non-mechs aren't people) online or in person what drivetrains are best since they work on more than just their own ride. Trucks suit long term ownership because they're easy to work on and valued enough to have large aftermarket parts support.

i like mine but finding parts for it is a massive motherfucker
also, be fucking careful when you remove the harmonic balancer/crank pulley and the flywheel
the engine is externally balanced, you have to mark everything before you pull it apart or the engine will be forever out of balance

posts.name: BigC
posts.com:
>>26273657
this also means if you use a different flywheel you need to purposefully make the new flywheel out of balance in the exact same way the mercedes one is, this is called match balancing
most engines are neutral balance and you don't need to bother with any of this, but mercedes are faggots
if i were to swap another diesel (i am going to) i would do a 1.9 tdi swap

The probability of you suffering that catastrophic engine failure (assuming you do the basic maintenance at the recommended intervals) is tiny. When you buy this kind of insurance/"warranty" you're gambling that you're going to suffer that worst case scenario, which the company has already determined to be statistically unlikely.
This is the poor stupid person's trap: paying $3000 today would be impossible, but $100 per month would be fine. Five years later the poor person has paid $6000 and most likely has received no benefit, while the person who had $3000 to spare, and therefore didn't buy the "warranty"/insurance, hasn't paid a dime. Are you a poor stupid person?

>>26261315
I might pick up a used nu-Ranger when this bullshit pricing ends. Any complaints about it? Hows the MPG?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26261328
MPG is meh, about 18 around town and 23 on roadtrips. (Those are actual calculations btw, not what the trip computer claims.) To be fair that's 4WD with A/T tires at relatively low pressure though, more street-oriented models should be a little better, and it's still better than other comparable midsize trucks. Mine needs a battery so the start/stop isn't working (really common issue with these, the stock batteries only last 2-3 years for some reason) and it might be a bit better with that fixed as well, people on the forums say it actually makes a couple of MPG difference on the Ranger.

Other than that I'm really happy with it. My only real complaints are about things that were available but not ordered by the original buyer, like the leather steering wheel, heated seats, sliding rear window, LED headlights, etc. Other than that the transmission can be a little clunky at times but no big deal, the suspension gets a little bouncy over specific road surfaces but that's an FX4-specific issue and replacement shocks are pretty cheap, the stock tires were trash but you're gonna replace those eventually anyway, etc.

A protip if you want one, see if there's an Avis dealer near you. Mine came from them and it was relatively high mileage for the year but exceptionally well-maintained, no bullshit upsells or anything from the dealer, and they've got really good no-haggle pricing, I got the top of KBB for my trade and well under KBB on the truck and didn't have to fight for it at all.

The Godfather hearse rolled back into the shop for a hemorrhaging trans leak. Of course, the seal was the one behind the viscous coupling, so I had to drop the trans. Hyrdamatic viscous couplings are sealed to the flywheel with a thin ass gasket and 38 bolts, which has to be the dumbest design I've ever seen. It's back in though.
Thanks for reading my blogpost

posts.name: laseranon
posts.com:
>>26252371
I actually couldn't tell you when they stopped using them, but I know they were developed in 1940, and this hearse is a '52, so they had quite a good run. The rest of the guts of the transmission are actually pretty solid and easy to work on, but I dispise the viscous coupling design. When pulling the motor or the trans, you have to drain 7qts out of the coupling and remove the nearly 40 bolts from the flywheel. And when re-installing it, you have to be absurdly careful to not bump or tear the thin paper torus gasket or you'll get the mother of all leaks since it's under a lot of pressure from the centrifugal force of the fluid spinning in the coupling.

posts.name: laseranon

>>26252611
It's not a torque converter since there is no reduction from the input to the output. It's just a viscous coupling that allows slippage between the front and back for the trans to shift while still being able to transfer power 1:1. There isnt a serperate rotor on the inside like there is in a TC, its just two halves of fins that rotate close to each other. So yeah, its more like a clutch, I suppose. That's not unique to this trans though, I've worked on a few others that have the same thing. Here's one out of a 50s Daimler I did a while back.
I doubt GM invented the concept, but I know they're definitely the first ones who ever used it in a production car.

posts.name: laseranon
posts.com:
>>26253207
A torque converter has a stator and has the ability to multiply torque at the output, sort of like a gear reduction. They're usually around a 2.5:1 reduction. A viscous coupling does not have a stator and can't multiply torque, it's best ratio is 1:1.
Also, >>26253215 is right. A torque converter uses the actual flow and direction of the fluid to transmit torque to the stator fins, whereas a viscous coupling simply uses the shear force of the fluid. I would assume it transmits power less efficiently than a torque converter, but I genuinely don't know.
>>26252978
Maybe, but I dont really think so. A torque converter gives the engine more mechanical advantage, especially if you're engineering a small economy car with a small engine.

>What are the issues?
Personally I think its a treat of a motor to work on...in a TR7, in a Saab it might be a different story.

As for problems
>Waterpumps like to fail, you will notice this looking at the weephole in the block its a day long job your first time as the intake has to come off.(A 3 hour job once you have pulled those intakes a few times, there are also some other things of note when working around the intake, pulling a waterpump.)
>Headgasket failure, buy a quality replacement gasket if you have to do a headgasket, it shouldn't fail unless the car has been overheated. Its a dog of a job if your head hasn't been removed in 40 years(mainly headstuds), but possible.
>Timing chain, it should give an audible warning before failure but its a hell of a job in a Saab I imagine.
>Idk what hell your fuel delivery system is on that thing. Either a single stromberg or KE jet I imagine.
Oh and 99 transmissions are...glass, and replacement parts are....a pain, but there is some autist guy in....Kentucky(?) I think who can get you parts. Almost bought a 99 that was owned by him or his kids or something.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26266950
>everyone hates the factory V12
Only those that can't handle anything but a SBC

>Corvette motor
Schmaybe. Pic related is a center-bolt valve cover L98 Corvette engine. Notice the valve covers are painted, not chrome. That intake is a TBI from a 90's pickup, as is the distributor (L98's had HEI) and the cast iron exhaust manifolds. That accessory drive set up is also 90's pickup. Note the difference in alternator mounting for one. Now it could be an L98 under all that other stuff but Occam's Razor suggests that they simply swung a 90's 5.0/5.7 TBI truck engine in there as being the simplest explanation. I also see a 700R4/4L60 TV cable there below the accelerator cable so it's got Overdrive at least. Not that it needs it, the original rear axle ratio is 2.87 iirc. Luckily you can get center sections up into the mid 4's if you want (and it probably desperately needs).

Also, not impressed by the cooling fan install that has poor coverage due to no shroud.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26268628
high pumping and line losses would make it very inefficient. a lot of the energy put into this system would be converted to heat due to fluid shear - before locking torque converters this was basically how transmissions worked and they were much less efficient than with locking.
also, since a modern transmission uses gears placed after the torque converter you can easily increase the torque to the wheels without increasing the max "pressure" or fluid shear within the converter.
the system you're proposing would have a direct correlation between line pressure and wheel torque assuming a static impeller size at the axle; to achieve similar wheel torque to a traditional axled vehicle i'm guessing the line pressure would be prohibitively high.

t. mechanical engineer

I'll smoke in the car but only occasionally. If you close the dash vents, but the heat on full blast on the floor, and crack the window where you're smoking, you'll only smell it for the next couple of days unless you do it extremely regularly.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: I used to smoke in my car all the time, even weed, but I just opened slightly the driver's window so the smoke would get suck out by the pressure. >>26272774

Fob issue. Either the fob is broken or the fob battery is dead. Probably a 2032 or 2016 coin battery. Get it at CVS/Walgreens where the hearing aids are. Open the fob with a flathead screwdriver or a pick and change it out, also swab it with a q-tip dipped in rubbing alcohol to clean out the dirt caked inside. Then reprogram.

If that doesn't work then the fob is just broken. Get your receipt and see if you can return it, if you bought it yourself. If the mechanic bought it then call him and see if he can do this under warranty. If he won't, then grab the part # and see if BB is able to order it for you. In my experience a new aftermarket fob will go for $100-300 depending on the brand.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Deals on these and most used cars are harder to come buy but they still exist. What I would consider a deal for an e46 would be under 150k miles, has been garaged or put in storage during winter so minimal rust, has evidence of preventative maintenance done or receipts for parts installed, and is under 6-8k depending on it’s motor and body configuration. The m54 are pretty stout but start burning oil around 150-200k miles because of the control rings. The m52tu motors found in the earlier 328i have better control rings so they don’t burn oil. Other than that and the subframe issue already mentioned there isn’t much that catastrophically go wrong with these cars unless they’re neglected on maintenance.

>planning to store some extra gas in the trunk.
Changes in temperature cause the gasoline can to breathe out fumes. In an enclosed trunk, there could eventually be enough fume concentration from either a cheap or a leaking gas container/nozzle assembly. Some trunks, like mine, have electronics with relays (thus spark).

If you do have a quality gas container that is well braced along with a cord tie down across its handle to keep it from tipping over, then you can carry it in the trunk. But why do you feel a need to carry gasoline?

Instead of a container, Just top off your car's gas tank as you drive past another gas station. There are plenty of stations everywhere. I like to stop and top off the tank because it also gives me a chance to get out of the car to strech my legs and walk around a bit.

>>26258013
How so?
EV are great for daily live and for people that can charge slowly at home
But for workers and long trips I see Hydrogen ICE (and fuel cell) as a possibility
An EV has about 280liters of battery space below the seats, convert that to hydrogen tanks and it's about 220l = 9kg at 700bar (180kg tanks)
On a fuel cell that's 500-700miles range, on a ICE it's 350-450miles
With the predicted (2030) 6$/kg H2 at the pump that's 8-10$/100miles on fuel cell or 12-14$/100miles for ICE
All without CO2 and NOx emissions (direct injection, EGR, lean burn)
Even if it's stupid... people would buy just for the feels

OP you have narcolepsy.

During periods when your brain is receiving low stimulus it will basically autopilot and you will have zero recollection of what happened during that time. People have the same problem with their loved ones. Euthanasia and getting people off life support have massive resistance and stigma when in a lot of cases it's the humane thing to allow the person to pass away when their time comes. But we keep them alive chained to a bed, possibly in a ton of pain, even though they themselves would want to already go because we're not ready to accept reality.

I've seen enough people with late stage cancer, dementia, etc. suffer just because their families aren't willing to accept that their time has come. And what do they gain in the end, couple more months of "life" where they're stick in a bed, in a lot of pain, and alone for most of the time because the same people that are too afraid to let go don't bother to visit them.

I've gotten deals from idiots often over many years. The reason we put a compression tester on every bike that came into the shop is what is not measured is not known.

OP should visit KZ 1000 forums. If the top end is good they're very solid machines and would be fine to learn to wrench on. Once you do then you have the motorbike world by the balls.

Filthy carbs/petcocks/tanks are the most common reason parked bikes don't start. They're easily dealt with and if things don't work out OP can part the bike out on Ebay easily enough while learning by disassembly and make a profit.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26270851
Online is typical for the reason most car testers don't have the motorcycle spark plug hole adapter sizes. About forty bucks should get a decent one.

The testers are simple Bourdon tube gauges (read how those work, theory of operation is key to knowledge) which are simple to use. Remember to hold the throttle fully open and have removed all four plugs to reduce resistance and go easy on starter and battery.

Shane Conley is a skilled instructor (I've trained many techs in aviation) so I recommend his videos. Look over his vids so you've an idea how to inspect.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=l4du6Z8Dw3w

I've been broken lads... I can't go back to sub ~100 horsepower street bikes. The rain did in the last of my tires on my fz1, so it's been cleaned and stowed away. New tires won't get here until after I'm already gone for a wedding and I'm not about to ride that bike with wires coming through the rubber. So I pulled my n400 out of storage for my commute. I feel nothing, Infact. I hate the performance. It's screaming at like 8k just to maintain 85 with a headwind. It feels like I've got to redline the motherfucker unless I want to shift 3 gears to get to 25mph. It's just... While it's still insanely light and flickable, I twist the throttle and nothing happens. I know it's faster than a lot of harmble layerrrdowns but compared to what I've ridden since, and what I daily now, there's no magic in the n400 anymore. I really have no regrets selling it now. It's a bike that's great at what it does, being entry level and a superb learning bike. The clutch is forgiving, it's extremely easy to maneuver at high and low speed, but compared to what I own now, I can never go back, it just makes me disappointed to ride.

No, because the electric cars of past eras were limited to lead acid batteries which couldn't even store the equivalent of a single gallon of gasoline. 5 years ago Tesla had only just hit 200k cars sold in the US total in the 10 years since the company started. Now they're selling ~500k cars in the US every year.
